Phillip Q. Maiorana Wastewater Plant
6301 West Erie Avenue
Lorain, OH 44053

The P.Q.M. Plant in the City of Lorain serves the sewer customers on the west side of Lorain and a portion of Amherst Township.  The population served is just over 15,000.  The treated water is discharged into Lake Erie after being disinfected with chlorine and de-chlorinated.  The plant has been in service since 1988.

APPLICABILITY

The P.Q.M. Plant has liquid chlorine in average inventory from 1000 to 5000 pounds.  This chlorine is contained in one-ton cylinders.  The maximum storage avaliable and stored at the plant is 8000 pounds.  Additionally, there are public receptors in the off site area.  Therefore, the plant is subject to program 3 requirements of 40CFR68.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There has been no release of chlorine in the past five years at the P.Q.M. Plant.

SAFETY AND PREVENTION PROGRAM

The P.Q.M. Plant has chlorine leak detectors located in the cylinder storage room and injection room.  These detectors have both visual and audio alarms located just above the outside entry doors,there is also an audio visual alarm located in the tunnel system just below the chlorine building, and all sensors are linked to the main computer SCADA system which alarms and trends all alarming events. These units are tested monthly and inspected several times during the day. also, there are automatic emergency shut offs on the main cylinder valves that will close when a leak is detected via the sensors. in addition, the chlorine system is fed via vacuum system which would minimize the amount of chlorine that could leak.  The material safety data sheet is located in the MSDS station in the maintenance garage and available to all Operators.

HAZARD REVIEW AND OPERATING PROCEDURES

We are dedicated to plant safety for the good of the public and all employees.  We update the emergecny contingency plan at least once a year.  Ths plan contains a section to instruct the Operators on how to handle

different chlorine situations.  The Operators also have a manual for standard procedures that was prepared by the design engineer, CT Consultants.

TRAINING

Each Operator is given on the job training.  All Operators are Class III certified and have been schooled and tested on the use and safety of chlorine.  Additionally, the employees are given drills and training in:
1.   Use of air packs
2.   Use of chlorine "B" kit
3.   Chlorine safety workshops
4.   CPR and first aid classes
5.   Books and videos on chlorine safety
6.   Emergency shut off system exercise and procedures
7.   Overall chlorine procedures from unloading a full cylinder to the loading of an     empty cylinder and everything in between (changing cylinders, reseting shut offs, shut off process, start up and shut down, just to name a few).

MAINTENANCE

All equipment is inspected several times a day visually.  The flex lines are replaced once a year, chlorine feed systems are rebuilt yearly, emergency shut offs are sent out for professional inspection on a regular schedule. If ever a leak would occur, we have parts readily available on site for replacement and emergencies.  The maintenacne program is followed either by the WEF MOP 11 or the manufacturers recommendations.

CONCLUSION

A leak event at the P.Q.M. Plant is unlikely.  We partake in good safety and maintenance practices.  All employees are well trained and fully respect  the potential danger of chlorine.  In the event of any leak, they are trained to respond quickly which would minimize the quantity that may escape. An emergency shut off system also assures the safety and well being of our employees and the genral public.

Safety is a well-coordinated effort between management and the employees.  We take our chlorine system serious and will continue to improve and update our safety procedures into the future.  This is why we have never had any chlorine leak events at the plant since its inception.  We expect to continue this good record.
